item.title: Green Beret Who Hit Child Rapist Should Be Reinstated, Lawmakers Say
item.description: Sgt. First Class Charles Martland faces discharge after he helped to beat up an Afghan militia commander who kept a boy chained to his bed as a sex slave.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: E.U. Leader Sends Economic Migrants a Blunt Warning: Don’t Come
item.description: The remarks by Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, signaled Europe’s determined turn away from Germany’s approach to absorbing migrants.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A Syrian family sat on railway tracks in the Greek border village of Idomeni on Thursday during a protest against the slow transit to Macedonia.

item.title: World Briefing: Spain Seizes 20,000 Military Uniforms Bound for ISIS
item.description: The uniforms were part of a shipment declared as “secondhand clothing” and were hidden inside three shipping containers intercepted in the ports of Valencia and Algeciras.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Remedy for China’s Economic Gloom Has Echoes of Reaganomics
item.description: “Supply-side structural reform” represents an effort to rejuvenate President Xi Jinping’s faltering plans to overhaul the Chinese economy.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Recruiters talked to job seekers at a job fair in Beijing last month. A whole generation of Chinese youth raised in a roaring economy over the past decade are coming of age in a period of material uncertainty as jobs come less easily.

item.title: Maryinka Journal: In Ukraine Towns Ravaged by War, Missionaries Find Fertile Ground
item.description: As Ukrainian forces and Russian-backed separatists carry on an almost forgotten fight, several evangelical groups are staging a campaign of their own.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei N. Kosyak led a service at the Christian Aid Center of the Transfiguration Church in Maryinka, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: South Africa's Highest Court Dismisses Pistorius Appeal
item.description: South Africa's highest court has dismissed Oscar Pistorius' appeal of his murder conviction, a lawyer said Thursday, signaling that the former track star's long legal battle since he killed girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp may be drawing to a close.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Indonesia’s Tsunami Warning System Was Out of Service When Quake Struck
item.description: The country relied on other nations’ systems because its own sea-based buoys had not been operable since last year.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: A sign for a tsunami evacuation route on Thursday, a day after a magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck far out at sea near Padang, West Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: My Father, the Editor, Under Fire
item.description: When the Bangladeshi government pursues a vendetta against a newspaper, its real target is press freedom.
item.dc:creator: TAHMIMA ANAM
item.media:description: Mahfuz Anam, center, editor of Bangladesh’s most widely circulated English newspaper, The Daily Star, leaving court on Tuesday.

item.title: In Mexico City, Comedians Punish Society’s Scofflaws With Humiliation
item.description: Meet the Supercívicos, comedians who embarrass the bad actors of Mexican society with their humor and then put videos of the shaming on social media.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arturo Hernández, left, and Alex Marin y Kall of the Supercívicos, an activist group of comedians whose mission is to embarrass the bad actors of Mexican society with punishing humor.

item.title: Sinosphere: Advisory Body’s Delegates Offer Glimpse Into China’s Worries
item.description: Participants discussed a range of topics they saw as priorities, including the importance of culture, poverty relief, housing costs and even dancing.
item.category: Great Hall of the People (Beijing, China)
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Delegates preparing to leave after the opening meeting of an advisory body in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Cuts Billions in Aid to Lebanon, Opening Door for Iran
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s tactic could allow Iran to increase its role in Lebanon through its ally, the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Supporters listened to Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s leader, in April in Beirut, Lebanon, in front of an image of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.

item.title: Spain’s Socialist Leader Fails in Effort to Become Prime Minister
item.description: The likelihood increases of new elections in June to help break the deadlock among the nation’s four main parties.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Pedro Sánchez, the leader of Spain’s Socialist party, in the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Death Toll in Ukraine Conflict Hits 9,160, U.N. Says
item.description: The number of casualties from fighting has fallen in recent months, a senior official said, but killings, abductions and torture are still being reported.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere: In Xi Jinping’s Tears, a Message for China’s People
item.description: The leader has had four documented cries since the 1960s, notes an article that spread widely in the state media, part of a broad effort to humanize him.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Hoang Dinh Nam
item.media:description: The Chinese state media has sought to humanize President Xi Jinping, also known by the nickname Xi Dada, meaning Daddy or Uncle Xi.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Britain Needs Europe
item.description: Boris Johnson sees himself as James Bond against Brussels. He’s on the wrong mission.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, bicycling along Oxford Street last month after an engagement with the queen.

item.title: In Saudi Arabia, a Kingdom to Myself
item.description: Untrammeled beaches, ancient sites and unfiltered local culture are all on offer in Saudi Arabia. Just don’t expect an easy trip.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times

item.title: Germany to Continue Funding to Establish Provenance of Looted Art
item.description: The country’s culture minister, who is visiting the United States, said that the effort is “what we owe the victims.”
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Monika Grütters, Germany’s culture minister, at the German Oscar nominees reception at the Villa Aurora in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles, last week.

item.title: Protesting Chinese Rule, Tibetan Monk Dies After Setting Himself Ablaze
item.description: It was the first known act of self-immolation in a Tibetan area of China since August.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Exiled Tibetans in Dharamsala, India, on Wednesday marching in support of two Tibetans who were said to have self-immolated in protest of Chinese rule.

item.title: New U.S. General Takes Command of Coalition Forces in Afghanistan
item.description: Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr. will lead a combined United States and NATO force of 13,000 troops, replacing Gen. John F. Campbell, who is retiring after a 37-year military career.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Dick Bradsell, Bartender Who Helped Revive London Cocktail Scene, Dies at 56
item.description: Mr. Bradsell’s influence was felt throughout Britain and as far away as Australia thanks to bartenders trained by him or inspired by his creations.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT SIMONSON
item.media:description: The bartender Dick Bradsell in an undated photo.
